Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I  learned skills on how to construct a genius novel, I   learned more about my home--the South and its people, I  re-kindled my love for reading.

I learned a lot about the South-- more than I came in with. I learned to think somewhat more intersectionally about the black and Southern experiences, and to see how different genres of writing lend themselves differently to different understandings of the black Southern history.

Literary Analysis! I haven't had the chance to take a lot of classes (or really any) that focus on it, and really struggled with it, but was able to really focus on it this semester, which was really good for me!
I read literature that I would've probably not have read otherwise.
I've learned a lot about Southern culture, and I read a lot of good books!
developing a greater understanding of black southern literature and its authors
STRENGTHS - everything. the class is brilliant and engaging
I think the strength is absolutely the material-- it's an incredible syllabus.

The perspectives of many students in this course were very similar to one another. While I recognize that there doesn't necessarily need to be an argument on every point, I think that it would be interesting to see what more differences in opinions could bring.

I really enjoyed the conversations as well as the presentations that each student made. They were all VERY VERY interesting and demonstrated important aspects of each student.
This is a fabulous class! Basically like a fun book club.

this course was absolutely wonderful in its dedication to the texts and the conversations that were held about the books in class. the course demanded that students came prepared to every class and had read the entirety of the texts. this course had little, if any weaknesses.

ABSOLUTELY; Take It. You are set up to learn no matter your background. Dean Mahurin is fair and insightful in a way that anyone can come in and take something valuable. The students are held to a high standard so you're learning from everyone in the space. She does have a final paper and a final exam which is a little annoying but the class makes It worth It. truthfully.
Yes, if you're interested in reading incredible prose and studying this part of America, highly recommend.
The best literature course I took at Yale.

Absolutely! This course has been an amazing experience, particularly as someone who hasn't been able to take a lot of classes doing literary analysis, and has been great! Everyone in the class is so amazing and always has so many great things to say  (and the end of semester party is so wholesome)

I believe everyone should read the Color Purple, Heavy, A Lesson Before Dying, and God's Trombones as well as everything on this syllabus. I've already recommended this course to white students and friends of mine who do not understand what the black experience and have not had much push back against their thoughts.

I do think all black people (especially black southerners) should take this class especially because these books were written for us. These books question our place and have made me reflect on my life and the position that I currently hold. They also provide a lot of insight into navigating America more generall speaking.
Take it!! Dean's a fabulous teacher, and everyone should read this set of books!

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone, even if they are not an Afam or English major. The syllabus is incredible and the topics discussed in class were insightful, relevant, and thought-provoking.
